_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Valero Renewable Fuels Company, LLC d/b/a Valero Mount Vernon Plant (Valero) dry mill ethanol production facility located in Mount Vernon, Indiana. The facility was recently purchased as part of an asset agreement. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The Valero ethanol facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of aqueous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance, and natural gasoline denaturant, a regulated flammable mixture, above the threshold quantities. The following policies relate to these regulated substances.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Valero is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public. Management goals include adherence to applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and ongoing training of our personnel, Valero is minimizing the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.



In the event that a release does occur, the facility's emergency response actions are described in its Facility Response Plan (FRP). The FRP includes procedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e. fire department, rescue contractors government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affected neighbors. 



Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The Valero facility is a 110 million gallon per y

ear corn-based dry-mill ethanol fuel production plant. Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a batch fermentation and continuous distillation process.



Regulated substances stored at the facility include aqueous ammonia, which is used for pH control and as a nutrient in the fermentation process, and natural gasoline, which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Valero has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, process safety management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations. The facility complies with PSM for the management of ethanol, denaturant (natural gasoline), and ammonia.



Employee Participation

Valero has developed an employee participation program. All process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, and action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel.



Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information

The facility utilizes the HAZOP methodology. The PHA identified the following potential major hazards: toxic release, fire, explosion, over-pressurization, corrosion, over-filling and equipment failure. The facility utilizes process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, alarms and procedures to prevent or limit releases.



Valero keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is pr

ovided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, piping and instrument drawings.



Operating Procedures and Training

Valero maintains written procedures that address process operations during normal, emergency, startup and shutdown. The facility develops and implements a training program for its employees involved in facility operations.



Contractors

The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities in order to assure that the contractor's employees follow safe work practices and procedures. The procedure includes a contractor screening process through a third party and site-specific safety orientation. .  Contractors are required to follow Valero's safe work practices.  



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Valero conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.



Hot Work Permit

Valero maintains procedures to obtain Hot Work Permits for any activity that generates a spark or a flame or serves as a possible source of ignition due to the presence of a flammable liquid/vapor or combustible dust.  Personnel are expected to confirm completion of all hot work requirements and acceptable atmospheric conditions before commencing any hot work operation.  The hot work permit also identifies possible work hazards, PPE, mitigations and energy control.



Mechanical Integrity

The facility's mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, and regular inspections and equipment testing procedures to mainta

in pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems, and controls in a safe operating condition.



Management of Change

The facility's management of change (MOC) program reviews  proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.



Incident Investigation

Valero has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.



Compliance Audits

The facility will conduct audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The audit will include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.



Accident History

The facility has not had any accidents reportable for the RMP regulated substances under Valero's ownership.



Emergency Response Program

Valero maintains a written emergency response program in its FRP. The purpose of the FRP is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The FRP addresses aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, medical response, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public In addition, Valero maintains, inspects, and te

sts emergency response equipment. Employees receive training as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. We work with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan. The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a new owner of this facility, Valero will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility. Modifications will be submitted as procedures affecting the RMP are updated.
